properties.Institution: Regents of the University of California, Berkeley

properties.Participants: Aubrey LaBrie [Project Director]; James Preston [Co Project Director]

properties.ProjectTitle: Support of a Conference to Explore Potential Application of Computer Science to the Advancement of Research in the Humanities
properties.ProjectDesc: Two-day conference whose principal function would be devoted to the discussion of retrieval systems and various techniques that have been established in attempting to coordinate discrete retrieval in various locations and disciplines. The conference would include representatives from the National Science Foundation, Library of Congress, American Council of Learned Societies, and other similarly informed organizations. The conference would also include a session devoted to a discussion of the possible future capabilities of computers and to the impact that this manifestation of various techniques might have upon the philosophy of knowledge.

properties.ProjectTitle: A Guideline for the Planning, Development and Organization of the Karl E. Mundt Archival Library

properties.Institution: Society for Health and Human Values
properties.ProjectTitle: A Study of Humanities Programs in Medical Settings
properties.Disciplines: History and Philosophy of Science, Technology, and Medicine

properties.ProjectTitle: A Study of Innovative American Colleges
properties.ProjectDesc: Study of experimental and innovative American colleges and college programs in the past century, with primary emphasis on differences in curricular philosophies. ABSTRACT: Study of experimental and innovative American colleges and college programs in the past century, with primary emphasis on differences in curricular philosophies. PI to compare not only stated philosophies but some of the differences in their underlying assumptions about the nature of the student, the definition of an "undeducated man," the nature and function of knowledge, the nature of education, and the relation of education to society.

properties.ProjectTitle: Center for Textual and Editorial Studies in Humanistic Sources
properties.ProjectDesc: Establishment and support for the Center for Textual and Editorial Studies in Humanistic Sources, a program for instruction of graduate students in the handling and editing of manuscript sources and printed text. Establishment and support for the Center for Textual and Editorial Studies in Humanistic Sources, a program for instruction of graduate students in the handling and editing of manuscript sources and printed texts. Consideration will be given to the transmission of literary and historical texts and to the principles of textual criticism and literary and historical editing. Primary purpose of center is to reintroduce American students of history and literature to concern for the integrity of the text upon which conclusions in the fields is based. Will prepare some of these students for careers as scholarly editors. Arrangements have been made with the University of Virginia Library, the Virginia Historical Society, the Library of the College of William and Mary, and the Research Department of colonial Williamsburg, Inc., to provide photographic copies of unedited manuscripts and printed materials to serve as texts for instruction in editorial procedures, which will result in a body of edited texts which have contributed to the training of the student editors which can then be published without further editing. Plans have been made for apprentice programs and/or lectures by the editorial staffs of the paper of George Washington, the John Marshall papers, the James Madison Papers and Stephen Crane's literary texts. Cooperation also planned with the Modern Language Association's Center for Editions of American Authors. Fund for first 2 years of projected 5 year project. Covers salaries, graduate fellowships, honoraria, travel, supplies, indirect costs.

properties.ProjectTitle: Planning for Improvement of the Humanities Curriculum in Public Schools
To Support Planning a Network to Enrich Humanities Scholarship, Research & Teaching
Summer Institutes on the Teaching of Humanities

properties.ProjectDesc: To establish the second Institute, which encourages interdisciplinary study and teaching. Senior and junior fellows throughout the country each devote a full year to intensive study, discussion, and curriculum materials development and testing. Upon return to their home institutions, they incorporate new interdisciplinary courses into their curriculum. Over a four year period, the Institute will enable 60 American instructors from two and four year colleges and universities throughout the country to participate. The theme, "Technology and the Humanities," will include such subjects as bureaucracy, myths, mass media, advertising and their implications for humanistic education

properties.Institution: SUNY Research Foundation, College at Brockport
properties.ProjectTitle: Participation by distinguished practitioners in conference of the Int'l Philosophy Year Project
properties.ProjectDesc: To present a two-quarter undergraduate course to American history using architecture as primary artifactual evidence and based on the premise that national history can best be taught through regional emphasis in architecture.

properties.ProjectTitle: Support of collaborative programs to enrich humanities scholarship and teaching
Planning for an integrated summer humanities program
properties.ProjectDesc: To support two conferences: the first to explore the possibility of teaching humanities within the framework of education in medicine; the second to recommend ways in which actual teaching problems could be put in operation in medical centers.

To offer two interdisciplinary social science courses, one for freshmen, one for seniors, which aim to enlighten the nature of social science by seeing it in the context of its own history and by seeing this history in the context of the development of modernity over the last two hundred years.

properties.ProjectTitle: A Study of African Art and the Preparation of a syllabus in this field
properties.ProjectDesc: To support two courses: l) an inquiry into the kind of weight that may be assigned to individuals in the historical process, and into the art of historical portraiture, and 2) an exploration of the role in America from the 1920's to the present of the interpreter of literature and the arts who is also a critic of society and politics. Issues posed by Edmund Wilson's writing will provide the foci of the two courses.

properties.ProjectTitle: The Role of the Humanities in the Rehabilitation of Young Criminal Offenders
properties.ProjectDesc: To implement 2 interdisciplinary, team-taught courses: "Perspectives on the American Dream, Philosophical, Literary, Religious and Historical"and "Perspectives on the 20th century: The Holocaust". The former examines ideals such as equality, liberty, and happiness. The latter examines the precedents, realities, and aftermath of genocide.
To fund a faculty seminar and a core course for an American Area Certificate Program. A-V methods will be used. Students will study folk and popular art as well as standard print materials.

To develop new interdisciplinary undergraduate course at UMR, which is primarily an engineering school. Course will bring together two faculty, a philosopher and a historian, with an interest in the relationships between technology and society and would combine the perspectives of both in examining the relationships between popular philosophies, historical situations, and the role of and attitudes toward technology, industrialization, and modernization.

To offer a year-long interdisciplinary undergraduate course that will relate culture, urban life, and questions of sex and gender. New York City will serve as a case study. Among the disciplines uses will be literature, anthropology, sociology, psychology, history, and law. Perspectives from the new scholarship about women will be drawn on.

properties.ProjectTitle: Program to improve instruction dealing with the American Negro
properties.ProjectDesc: This is one of seven "summer workshops on Negro history and culture for college and university faculty members" funded by the NEH during 1968.

properties.ProjectTitle: Program to improve instruction dealing with the American negro
properties.ProjectDesc: This is one of seven "summer workshops on Negro history and culture for college and university faculty members" funded by the NEH during 1968.

properties.ProjectTitle: Program to improve instruction dealing with the American Negro
properties.ProjectDesc: This is one of seven "summer workshops on Negro history and culture for college and university faculty members" funded by the NEH during 1968.

properties.ProjectTitle: The Black Man in American Music
properties.ProjectDesc: A three-phase project to advance knowledge of the music of the black man through 1) research and consultation to gather essential information about black music hitherto not available in any organized fashion; 2) establishment of three credit college humanities course on “The Black Man in American Music;” 3) presentation of 17 seminars during 1969-70 to the general public on black music, art, literature and five black music programs. Outlines for use in college teaching with lists of books, recordings, slides, films, tapes, etc. to be developed and published. Participating schools will send teachers, counselors, etc. to the seminars, as well as 150 Virginia State College seniors, who will participate in the seminars in preparation for their teaching. The mailing list of the Department of Continuing Education and Human Relations will be used to publicize the seminars to the public. Funds for salaries and wages, supplies, materials, travel.
properties.Participants: Altona Johns [Project Director]; Undine Moore [Co Project Director]

properties.ProjectDesc: To establish an Institute to study the African humanities, emphasizing multidisciplinary studies of Aschanti, Yoruba and Zulu. 48 undergraduate teachers will be selected from Liberal Arts colleges nationwide. Participants will each compile a syllabus for use in their home college.

To plan, develop, and offer a course ("Communication Policy and Planning") in the undergraduate curriculum, Department of Communication. 35 students from all disciplines may enroll. Course emphasis is placed on the individual's active participation in his world working from an ethic of communication based on peace, freedom, mutual respect, cultural and political diversity, and man's intrinsic worth or dignity. Field trips, videotapes, and films will augment traditional course materials.

properties.Institution: SUNY Research Foundation, College at Brockport
properties.ProjectDesc: To develop a new approach to teaching both anthropology and drama, with a focus on human values. In each semester, class work will be used to develop and test materials for the institutes. Work will involve the exploration of ethnographies and dramatic literature primarily through controlled improvisation, and will focus on different topics dealing with values and belief as well as behavior.

properties.ProjectTitle: Symposium on Language, Symbol and Reality
properties.ProjectDesc: Symposium on the possible interrelationship in the use of symbols in diverse disciplines. Confronts speakers with the problem of a common basis for a definition of the terms "symbols" and "symbolism." ABSTRACT: Symposium on the possible interrelationship in the use of symbols in diverse disciplines (e.g., the arts, linguistics, philosophy, theology, the social and physical sciences), November 7-9, 1969. Confronts speakers with the problem of a common basis for a definition of the terms "symbol" and "symbolism," to facilitate an understanding of the extent and manner in which modern man uses symbols and of the ways in which thoughts and actions are shaped by the kinds of symbols used. The study, originating as it does in the humanities, serves to highlight the importance of insights gained in humanistic disciplines and their significant practical applicability to human thought and action. Speakers include Meyer Shapiro (art), David Crabb (anthropology), S.I. Hayakawa (general semantics), Michael Butor (literature), Karl Manniger (psychiatry), Paul Ricoeur (philosophy), Roman Jakobson (linguistics), and Rulon Wells, An art exhibit, entitled "Sign, Symbol and Reality," will be presented in conjunction with the symposium. Parts of the symposium videotaped, with closed-circuit airing of the videotape in class rooms and over Educational TV. Proceedings to be published. Funds for honoraria, travel and per diem for 8 speakers and 1 consultant; stenotypist; videotaping.

properties.ProjectTitle: Hampshire College: Experimental Curriculum in Humanities and Arts for Undergraduates
properties.ProjectDesc: Development of Humanities and Arts curriculum for Hampshire College, an experimental college brought into being by Amherst, Mt. Holyoke, Smith and University of Massachusetts. Flexible format allows continuing experimentation and innovation in teaching methods, media, materials. ABSTRACT: Hampshire College intended as a national pilot enterprise for innovations in liberal education. Brought into being through initiative of Amherst, Mt. Holyoke, Smith and University of Massachusetts to emphasize artistic experience within flexible academic format to make possible productive interplay between study and performance, inquire and expression, relating these to the quality and conditions of life. Liberal arts college to much preoccupied by questions of institutional survival, hierarchical relationships of faculty, organizations and procedure. Students disaffection suggests need for new commitment of liberal education to serve as encounter with contemporary man's condition. Humanities and arts central to meaningful curriculum. Unusually flexible academic format will allow continuing experimentation with new teaching methods, media, materials. Funds to support planning faculty of 5, consultants.

Project enables teams of humanists to work with the faculties of secondary schools or school systems for approximately 20 faculty days a term to create better teaching of the humanities at the secondary school level. ABSTRACT: Project enables teams of four to five humanists to work with the faculties of secondary schools or school systems for approximately 20 faculty days a term to create better teaching of the humanities at the secondary school level. Program administered by an Executive Director responsible to NHF Board consisting of representatives from Phi Beta Kappa, American Council of Learned Societies, American Council on Education, 12 individuals from colleges, school systems and various humanities areas. In first year of program, 1968-69, faculty visited school systems in 5 cities; in 1969-70, program expanded to 15 cities, including 2 renewals. Present proposal for 1970-71, under this grant, to support 10 projects to permit greater flexibility in the time spent by the Faculty with any one school system. Funds for administrative expenses: NHF honoraria, travel; evaluation conference; indirect costs.

properties.ProjectTitle: Experimental General Education Course in War and Peace
properties.ProjectDesc: Interdisciplinary course on War and Peace to be team-taught by 3 professors, representing natural science, the social sciences, and the humanities. ABSTRACT: Development of an interdisciplinary course on War and Peace to be team-taught by 3 professors, representing the natural science, the social sciences, and the humanities. Moving from microcosm to macrocosm, man and animals will be studied in the light of psychological insight into frustration, aggression, and conflict. Sociological theory will then be added to see whether conflict is "built into" the institution and society which man constructs. Historical study of contemporary wars, scientific date on thermonuclear and biological warfare, the "just war" concept, and non0violent alternatives to war will all be studied. Course consist of weekly lectures and discussion sections. Course to be required of all students; taken during junior or senior years. Funds for salaries, travel, supplies, consultant fees.

properties.Institution: Boston Council for Public Schools, Inc.

properties.ProjectTitle: Staff Development for Teaching Negro History and Culture

properties.ProjectDesc: Three summer enrichment programs for disadvantaged high school students. ABSTRACT: Summer enrichment program for disadvantaged high school students. Three-part program: 1) A Better Chance (ABC) program, takes 9th and 10th grade students from limited education backgrounds and, after a summer of intensive study, places them in preparatory and secondary schools from which they have a better chance to proceed to college. 2) Smith-Amherst Tutorial Program (SATP), helps high school students overcome educational deficiencies through tutorial work in 2 consecutive summers. 3) English Teacher's Institute (ETI) for secondary school teachers from the Springfield, Massachusetts, school system, emphasizing English as an activity every individual engages in whenever he speaks, reads, or writes. The ETI and SATP programs are coordinated to provide interaction between teachers and students during the course of the summer. Program created as a result of the Black-White Action Committee formed after Martin Luther King's assassination to outline reforms designed to improve racial relations. Summer Action Programs designed to involve Amherst in the surrounding community and to put the college's resources to good use during the summer months. Funds for faculty salaries.

properties.ProjectTitle: Development of Social Science Curriculum Units on Mexican-American Culture
properties.ProjectDesc: Development of curriculum materials in the social sciences for Mexican-American students, with dissemination of results in five Southwestern states. ABSTRACT: Development of curriculum materials in the social sciences for Mexican-American students, with dissemination of results in five Southwestern states. Concentration on several areas: 1) 16 curriculum units with teachers' manuals, high school and junior high level, centering on prominent figure in Mexican history and designed to encourage sense of cultural identity; 2) 6 children's books at the elementary level (grade 4); 3) film-strip focusing on aspects of Mexican history. Additional units developed under NEH grant EO-253-70-4650. Traditional curricula tend to ignore the Mexican culture and present the Mexican-American child with Dick-and-Jane type, "Anglo" curriculum materials. Child is unable to identify with visual materials presented and is often hampered in learning to read because the content of the primary books not only reflects middle class values different from the child's own but also ignores his individual heritage. To reverse the high drop-out rate and low literacy level among Mexican Americans it is necessary to present materials which recognize their values and the worth of their culture. Funds for salaries, consultants, publication costs

Program runs concurrently with D.C. school year, offers elective credit in lieu of elective courses from regular curriculum at Eastern High School. Two 3-hour sessions daily in Black History, Black Literature, Black Philosophy, Community Organization, Third World Studies, Contemporary Problems, Economics, Black Art and Drama, Black Music, Swahili. ABSTRACT: Eastern High School Freedom Annex, established by a group of students at that school, offers a curriculum to run concurrently with the D.C. school year and is available for full elective credit in lieu of elective courses from the regular curriculum at Eastern High. Two 3-hour sessions each day--to keep classes small--consist of a one-hour class, a one-hour small group discussion, and a one-hour creative workshop. Black History, Black Literature, Black Philosophy, Community Organization, Third World Studies, Contemporary Problem, Economics, Black Art and Drama, Black Music and Swahili offered. A competent teaching staff has been found. Space is provided without charge by a neighboring Lutheran church. NEH staff visitors have found that the school appears to be functioning well. Many poor students, including previous drop-outs, are being stimulated into genuine study by program. Fine and rapidly growning library. Student group is involved in other projects, some involving the community. Started in 1969 with NEH funding for salaries (H69-0-42).

properties.ProjectTitle: The Conception and Use of the Family in Political Theory
properties.ProjectDesc: Study of the concept of family in the political theory of major writers from classical Greeks through Marx and Engels (Plato, Aristotle, Bodin, Hobbes, Filmer, Locke, Rousseau, Hume, Marx). Much concern among behavioral social scientist about the role of the family in political and cultural socialization but little study has been make of the roles that political theorist have attributed to the family. Fellow's dissertation, Leviathan Writ Small: Thomas Hobbes on the Family, dealt with Hobbes' conception of the family as an instrument of education and as an anaology to the state.

properties.ProjectTitle: Fellowships for Winterthur Program in Early American Culture
properties.Program: Humanities Projects in Museums and Historical Organizations
properties.ProjectDesc: Training program at the Winterthur Museum in conjunction with the University of Delaware to help fill increasing need for qualified historical society and museum personnel. ABSTRACT: Since 1952 Winterthur Museum and University of Delaware have collaborated in an interdisciplinary program for the training of personnel for humanistic museums and historical societies. Program covers 2 academic years, one full summer and part of another, during which the Fellow takes a total of 41 hours of course work at the University and the Museum, 6 hours of thesis work, includes both practical and theoretical problems related to collections of American artifacts and the conservation, preservation, presentation and interpretation thereof. Leads to M.A. degree. Graduates in great demand because of excellence of training and ever increasing need for qualified museum personnel. Funds for 5 Fellow' stipends, tuition and dependency allowance.

properties.Program: Humanities Projects in Museums and Historical Organizations
properties.ProjectDesc: Internship program to strengthen the personnel of small museums by sending them to larger museums for one year for training. ABSTRACT: This internship is one of several which were supported during fiscal year 1970. The general purpose of teh internship program is to strengthen the personnel of small museums. Certain larger museums agreed to take an intern for training purposes for a period of approximately one year. Grant funds to the larger museum include costs for the intern's salary and transportation, and a small amount for administrative costs. It is understood that, if appropriate arrangements can be made, the intern is to return to his home museum, after completion of his training.

properties.Program: Humanities Projects in Museums and Historical Organizations

Grant funds to the larger museum include costs for the intern's salary and transportation, and a small amount for administrative costs. It is understood that, if appropriate arrangements can be made, the intern is to return to his home museum, after completion of his training.

properties.ProjectTitle: To Support Selection, Production, and Distribution of Model Instructional TV Programs in Humanities, and Study Programs
Film Documenting the Traditional Culture of the Blackfeet Indians of Northwestern Montana
Production of a Television Series entitled "Human Concerns Expressed in the Arts"

properties.ProjectDesc: Series of presentations, based on general theme, "Time Out for Man," conducted by scholars and performers from disciplines within the humanities and social sciences for non-academic audience in 43 culturally remote U.S. communities. ABSTRACT: Series of presentations, based on general theme, "Time Out for Man," conducted by scholars and performers from disciplines within the humanities and social sciences for non-academic audiences in 43 culturally remote U.S. communities. Six humanities teams (one professor and 2 or 3 performers) employed variety of media and methods to extend and communicate their knowledge to the public; to stimulate public interest in educational opportunity and to demonstrate the need for the humanist in complex and technological world. Each community received three, two-day visits, a different team for each visit. Topics for three performances were, "The Private Sphere," man's personal relationships; "The Human Community," man and society, cooperation and conflict; and "The Good Life," man and environment, response to technology and nature. Performances given for general audiences, service, civic, church and social organizations, as well as some high school and community college groups, reaching over 126,000 people in 21 states, from February to May 1970. Evaluation by audiences, participants, NEH staff members indicates that programs were educationally solid. Significant in improving public adult education, improving local leadership, bringing humanities to large groups of people and breaking down barrier between community and academia. Funds for program director, visiting scholars, secretary, telephone, printing, office supplies, rent and insurance.

properties.ProjectDesc: Training program in archeology June 16-August 8, 1969. College anthropology majors with previous archeological experience train and supervise high school students in the excavation of an Indian village. ABSTRACT: Training program in archeology June 16-August 8, 1969. College anthropology majors with previous archeological experience train and supervise high school students in the excavation of an Indian village (c. 1450-1550 A.D.), located in Washington Boro, Pennsylvania. Project introduces high school students to archeological study and techniques while providing teaching experience for college students. Provided valuable experience in dealing with preliterate culture. From an archeological standpoint the unearthing of a major portion of a large Indian village was a major accompliment, since it revealed that the Shenk's Ferry Indians (an aboriginal tribe that inhabited the lower Susquehanna Valley in the 15th century), previously considered a wandering tribe which built campsites rather than fixed villages, built at least one village housing nearly 1000 Indians. Funds for 4 college students, 12 high school students, visiting lecturers, bulldozing and crop damage.

properties.ProjectDesc: To prepare one-volume dictionary to include historical and archeological data on every known site of the classical world. ABSTRACT: Continuation of H68-0-90, to prepare one-volume dictionary to include historical and archeological data on every known site of the colassical world--Greece, Crete, Asia Minor, Levant, North Africa, Sicily, Italy, Graeco-Roman Europe and Britain. Entries arranged alphabetically by location of sites, and each to contain a survey of the history of the site, a description of the monuments, the facts of excavation, a bibliography, and a map and plans according to sites' importance. Aim to provide an authorative reference work for students and scholars in the fields of classical archeology, history and literature. Personnel for project selected; initial survey of sites finished. Contracts for manuscripts now complete for 750 sites (volume will contain 2000); 242 completed manuscripts received. Funds for salaries, drafting, translations, operation expenses.

properties.ProjectTitle: Historical Backround of Concept of Checks and Balances in the United States
properties.ProjectDesc: Funds to complete a study of the origins of concept of checks and balances in government, beginning in 6th century B.C. and its subsequent theoretical and practical development as a means of accomodating conflicting forces within a state. ABSTRACT: Funds to complete a study of the origins of concept of checks and balances in government, beginning in 6th century B.C. and its subsequent theoretical and practical development as a means of accomodating conflicting forces within a state. In every historical instance where a revival of the concept of check and balances occurs, socio-economic conflicts and scientific theories used to justify the view that distribution of powers by law to opposite social and political forces can produce a balanced and stable state. Emphasizes the transmission of concept to Revolutionary generation in America; the way it was embodied in the Constitutuion; significance of Founding Fathers' contribution and relevance of their solution to contemporary conflict between the established order and dynamic minorities in the United States. Subject is part of the background of the American system of government, relevance to Bicentennial.

properties.ProjectTitle: Photo Reference Collection at the American Academy in Rome
properties.ProjectDesc: Collection has comprehensive archive of photographs of Roman architecture and topography, steadily being increased and kept up-to-date. ABSTRACT: Funds to subsidize operations for one year. Collection has a comprehensive archive of photographs of Roman architecture and topography with cross-reference bibliographic information steadily being increased and kept up-to-date, and also provides a service, drawing upon all available photographic sources, filling at a reasonable cost all requests for photographs dealing with the entire field of History of Ancient and Classical Art and Architecture in Italy. History of Art and Architecture is presently taught at every major university in US at undergraduate and graduate levels. Photograph is single most important tool in preparation and teaching of such courses. Collection has furnished study materials and whole core collections making it possible for them to introduce courses they were never equipped to teach before. In addition, Collection is the only place in the world where scholars and students can make visual comparisons among widely geographically scattered objects that lead to new knowledge. Collection has served for 12 years as an indespensible tool of scholarship and teaching, serving numerous American universities and colleges as well as hundreds of individual scholars.

properties.ProjectTitle: Comparative Study of Metallurgy in Old and New Worlds
properties.ProjectDesc: Use of modern metallurgic techniques to determine techniques used in pre-Columbian America and in Cyprus. Excavation of ancient city of Chan Chan in Peru with analysis of gilding techniques. Excavation of copper smelting and foundry sites at Kition in Cyprus. ABSTRACT: Use of methods of modern material science laboratory to examine selected artifacts in order to reconstruct in detail the methods of manufacture. Two-part project: 1) study of gilding techniques in pre-Columbian America, especially to trace the temporal and geographic development of the newly-discovered process used in N. Peru for large masks and other sheet metal "gold" objects; participation of research associate in the Harvard excavation at the ancient city of Chan Chan to seek evidence in the known metal workshops there, with detailed laboratory analysis of materials from the excavation and confirmation of the techniques by duplication; 2) excavation of the copper-smelting and foundry sites at Kition in Cyprus, as part of the major excavation by the Cypriot Department of Antiquities. Continuation of H68-0-86. Since the properties of matter remain constant, the way in which techniques change with time within one culture, and diffuse or originate within different geographic areas can be traced in considerable detail. By relating changes in techniques to other cultural factors, these studies in metallurgy contribute to an understanding of technology's part in the basic human experience. Funds for salaries (research associate, assistant professor, secretary), travel, materials, services, overhead.

Project to provide English translations of important Asian sources and works in the humanities. ABSTRACT: Project to provide English translations of important Asian sources and works in the humanities (e.g. works in Bengali, Burmese, Javanese, Indonesian, Vietnemese, Korean, Japanese and Chinese). Completed project will provide scholars, students and interested public with the means to identify esthetic, spiritual and social values of a given Asian society as expressed in its own literature. Although many books about Asia exist, to date, few works written by Asians are available to the non-specialist because they have not been translated. A knowledge of the humanistic thought of Asia from the Asian point of view will contribute greatly toward providing a base for intelligent decision-making regarding US interests in Asia and toward giving Asian studies its rightful place in the humanistic heritage of the world. The Asian Society has supported research and translation of Asian works since 1959. Funds for travel, per diem, editorial consultation, translation fees, operation expenses.

properties.ProjectTitle: A Literary Investigation of American Popular Culture
properties.ProjectDesc: To continue and encourage investigations of the contributions of "popular" literature to the creation and maintenance of important American myths, images and self-images. To continue and possibly complete investigations into the origins, development and exploitation of the "Western" as a literary genre, a myth and cultural form.

properties.ProjectTitle: Watts Writers Workshop and Affiliated Branches
properties.Program: State Humanities Councils General Operating Support Grants
properties.ProjectDesc: Douglass House workshops, cultural centers in ghetto communities designed to develop and nurture creative talents in the arts and humanities. Idea originated in Watts after the 1965 riots.

properties.ProjectDesc: Purposes of NEH grant is to cover the difference between income and essential operating cost of the ACLS and enable it to continue its major role of stimulating and coordinating humanistic scholarship in the U.S.

Development of interrrelated MA and PhD programs in American Studies (with a focus on Negro-White realions in an urban context) at Emory and Atlanta Universities. ABSTRACT: Development of new inter-institutional programs between Atlanta and Emory Universities. Emory is developing a new curriculum, within its on-going American Studies PhD program, centered on social change in an urban context, with the focus on Negro-White relationships, interactions and polarization. Atlanta to develop MA program in American Studies and hopes eventually to establish a PhD curriculum in American Studies parallel to that of the new Emory program. Until Atlanta establishes its projected PhD program, its MA students will normally enter the new Emory doctoral program after their first year of graduate study. Both programs depend on close inter-institutional cooperation, pooling resources rather than duplicating each other. Three joint faculty appointments (in such areas as history, anthropology, sociology, political science, economics, literature and language). Approximately 1/3 of the time of students in the 3rd year of the new doctoral curriculum will be committed to teaching in the Atlanta area, in either a predominantly Negro college or a predominantly white college in the process of racial integration. Funds for faculty salaries, travel, student stipends.

properties.ProjectDesc: Support (a) the preparation, implementation and refining of an interdisciplinary course and (b) the subsequent planning of a 90-minute film on Chicago and its White City of 1893. Offered under the auspices of the Program in American Culture and the History of Art Department, the Course will stress the relation of artistic expression to social structure.

properties.ProjectTitle: Support for activities of the Institute of Southern History
properties.ProjectDesc: To develop a new course titled "The Indian in American History" which will serve as an interdisciplinary introduction to American ethnic studies. The course will have as a basic unifying concept the study of the ethno-historic frontier: the pattern of confrontation and interaction which occurs when two dissimilar cultures come into contact with each other. An evaluative report will be disseminated.

properties.ProjectTitle: Humanities Institute in connection with the Graduate School of Urban Affairs
properties.ProjectDesc: To develop a course designed to utilize heuristically the conflicting views of art history (art as stylistic artifact) and social history (art as cultural artifact). Course will serve as a model for other interdisciplinary courses to continue in the College curriculum the interpretation of works of art as cultural artifacts.
properties.Participants: Irving Bartlett [Project Director]; Erwin Steinberg [Co Project Director]

properties.ProjectTitle: A Workshop Conference on the Creative Arts and Liberal Education
properties.ProjectDesc: To further training of college and university teachers of Afro- American culture, the University will sponsor a 2-week summer institute on "Black Culture in the 2nd Renaissance," providing lectures and discussions on such topics as the Black Arts Movement, The Black Aesthetic, Desegregation in Education, Images of Black Women, among others.

properties.Institution: Council for Intercultural Studies and Programs
properties.ProjectTitle: College Professor-High School Teacher Team Teaching
properties.ProjectDesc: To create two new courses "Television As Popular Culture" and "The Electric Media" in the Department of Popular Culture. Both courses will be interdisciplinary in scope and approach, and outside speakers, visitors etc., will be utilized in order to provide vital perspectives for an adequate overview of the culturally significant topics covered in the courses.

properties.ProjectTitle: Project SHARE--Curriculum Research in the Humanities and Social Sciences
properties.ProjectDesc: To fund a colloquial entitled "Adolescent Values in English History and Literature." The course will demand study of representative documents from different historical periods which help clarify the connection between personal feelings and social expectations and values. The program will be evaluated and publicized.

properties.ProjectTitle: Program to improve instruction dealing with the American Negro
properties.ProjectDesc: This is one of seven "summer workshops on Negro history and culture for college and university faculty members" funded by the NEH during 1968.

properties.Institution: Council for Intercultural Studies and Programs
properties.ProjectTitle: Documentary Films on Indian Classical Music
properties.ProjectDesc: Project to product four 26 minute 16mm color films for use in high school, college and university humanities programs, educational TV, on Indian classical music. ABSTRACT: Project to product four 26 minute 16mm color films for use in high school, college and university humanities programs, educational TV, on Indian classical music. Films designed to portray four major ragas, a traditional melodic form in Hindu music, within the context of the total Indian culture, showing the interdependence of music and dance, and their relation to Indian philosophy and religion. Project designed to counteract over-emphasis on Western humanistic studies in traditional American college humanities courses, and the current distortion in Western popular music of Indian classical forms.

Graduate in civil engineering with emphasis on the cultural impact of technology. ABSTRACT: Graduate program in civil engineering with emphasis on the cultural impact of technology. Aimed at producing a new type of engineer who, while fully competent in engineering design, will center his career on a union of technology with the humanities, either in practice or in teaching. Emphasis on historical development of architectural and engineering forms, including analysis of the relationship between efficiency and elegance in well-known structures. Technology, having in the recent past provided the basis for industrialism, needs in the near future to be focused on the means for creating a more human life. Until engineers recognized that within their own tradition there exist works of humane elegance to serve as prototypes for new designs, they will not be be likely to answers, by better designs or more vigorous criticisms of their own, the charges of ugly engineering and short-sighted policies. Project designed to make engineers more aware of the human as well as technical factors involved in their work. Funds for salaries, equipment, travel, computer time, and indirect costs.
properties.Disciplines: History and Philosophy of Science, Technology, and Medicine

properties.ProjectDesc: Collection of objects of material culture to be used for exhibits showing the rapid changes in the culture of the natives of Alaska and adaptation to those changes. ABSTRACT: Phase I: documentation of the rapid acculturation of the native people of Alaska by collecting objects of material culture that illustrate this change and devlopment of a systemized approach to recording the use and cultural context of these materials. Phase II: collection, supported by sociological information, will be basis of two types of interpretive exhibits directed toward 1) urban populations, predominantly new Alaskans and unaware of the social and economic situation outside of the urban area; and 2) the rural, isolated population, predominantly native, which needs insight and understanding of its own adaptation through time to help it survive in a changing society. Total project designed to illustrate the adaptability of Alaskan native populations to constant pressures for change. Provides some insights into the way this change may continue without the complete loss of cultural activities. Funds for Phase I: salaries (PI and assistants), informants, supplies, travel, indirect costs.

properties.ToSupport: The worldwide search, cataloguing, and preparation for publication of documents relating to the American founder, military leader, and first president of the United States.

properties.ProjectTitle: Urban Society at the End of the Revolution: Annapolis 1782-86, Community and Congress
properties.ProjectDesc: Project to re-create the community of Annapolis, Maryland as it existed from 1782-1786 in a book or series of articles which will enhance historical understanding of this important 18th century urban cultural and political center. ABSTRACT: Project purposes to re-create the community of Annapolis, Maryland as it existed from 1782-86 in a book or series of articles which will enhance historical understanding of this important 18th century urban cultural and political center and, therefore, illuminate a significant segment of national heritage. During the period under study, Annapolis played important role in nurturing the nation's new government, serving for a time as the U.S. capital, as the site of the Confederation Congress and of the Annapolis convention (which resulted in the Constitutional Convention). Will question how revolutionary Annopolis was structured economically, socially and politically and how it functioned. Emphasis on physical similarities of present city to past community in effort to relate community to its environment. Annapolis particularly suited to project because of its well-preserved state and the availability of records and documents regarding the city and its historic development. Other purposes of the project are to improve present community spirit and involvment and to development knowledge that will serve as incentive for an historical restoration and interpretation program. Fund for salaries, supplies, computer time, travel.

properties.ProjectTitle: Edition of the Papers of Robert Morris

properties.Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
properties.ProjectTitle: International Repertory of Music Literature Project
Center for Editions of American Authors
properties.ProjectDesc: This project aims to produce full, accurate texts of eight American authors: Clemens (Mark Twain), Crane, Emerson, Hawthorne, Howells, Irving, Thoreau, Whitman. Many works are available only in old, incomplete, and inaccurate editions long since out of print, which hampers diffusion of American culture both at home and abroad. Center editions will exclude errors compiled through frequent reprintings but will include changes made by the author himself in later editions. The Center will control disbursement of funds so editors' salaries and collating cost result in finished manuscripts according to schedule, and will insure replacment of editor and continuation of work should the original editor be unable to complete their work. The Center provides a uniform editorial manual, the Guide to Editorial Principles, which serves both as a research tool for the project and as a reference work for other scholars. Paperback editions will be produced from many of the same plates, encouraging dissemination of accurate texts to students and the public at low cost. This will provide accurate texts for scholars, teachers, students, and the reading public.

Coleridge in the 20th Century: An Annotated Bibliography and Review of Scholarship
properties.ProjectDesc: Research to produce 20th century portion of a definitive, annotated and subject-indexed bibliography of material pertaining to, but not by, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, together with substantial essays on the reputation of Coleridge and a review of Coleridge scholarship in the U.S. ABSTRACT: Research to produce 20th century portion of a definitive, annotated and subject-indexed bibliography of material pertaining to, but not by, Samuel Taylor Coleridge (1772-1834), together with substantial essays on the reputation of Coleridge and a review of Coleridge scholarship in the U.S., Great Britain and elsewhere. All entries will contain complete bibliographical data, brief abstracts or descriptions and (for more substantial items) lists of reviews. Entire work (covering period 1794-1969) will be thoroughly indexed and cross-referenced with aid of a computer. Coleridge's work of interest to modern readers; he was poet, literary critic, aesthetician, philosopher, theologian, and political theorist; his work affected by and affecting English and German workers in these fields. His work has had prodound influence on American literature and thought. Bibliography will highlight important points and gaps, suggesting new directions for future work; indexes will identify general and specific topics, indicating over-worked neglected or overlooked topics; identify all significant and most of insignificant material pertaining to Coleridge, minimizing likelihood that old discoveries of fact and insight will continue to be published as new. Significant contribution to study of use of computers in humanistic research.

Project to locate, select, and edit the more important personal and public papers of Jonathan Trumbull, Sr. (1710-1785), governor of Connecticut before and during the Revolution. ABSTRACT: Project to locate, select, and edit the more important personal and public papers of Jonathan Trumbull, Sr. (1710-1785). Trumbull, governor of Connecticut before and during the Revolution (1769-84), provided supplies for the Continental Army (Connecticut became known as the "Provision State"), helped to mobilize Connecticut sentiment in favor of independence so that the Loyalist threat was far less there than in most other states. Close relationship with Washington. Trumbull important second-tier figure in American history. No comprehensive collection of his works in existence. Funds for PI's salary, assistant editor, secretarial assistance, supplies.

properties.ProjectTitle: Compilation of Discography of Hillbilly Reocrdings
properties.ProjectDesc: Project to collect and catalogue all hillbilly/country music recording produced by one of the major recording companies of the period, 1923-47, prior to introduction of LP recordings. ABSTRACT: Project to collect and catalogue all hillbilly/country music recording produced by one of the major recording companies of the period, 1923-47, prior to introduction of LP recordings. Project will conserve data that will otherwise soon be lost. Sound recordings are a serious communication medium, relevant to understanding much older American music as well as an important source of folklore and culture. Popular music reflects the character and lifestyle of America. Project will produce important source of data on American society and culture for historians, anthropologists and musicologists. Funds to be used to gather material, recordings, production data, bibographical information, background information, and to interview artist and personnel from period. Grantee organization a group of expert folklorists and students of popular culture at Folklore and Mythology Center, UCLA. Collection will be house at UCLA Folklore and Mythology Center as part of John Edwards Memorial Foundation Collection.

properties.ProjectTitle: What is Party? An Inquiry Concerning Political Science and Party Theory
properties.ProjectDesc: Funds to support writing of book to develop a definition of the concept of "party" and partisanship by examining both contemporary and classical views of party. ABSTRACT: Funds to support writing of book, research for which is nearly complete, to develop a definition of the concept of "party" and partisanship by examining both conemporary and classical (i.e. Plato, Aristotle, Machiavelli, Burke, Toqueville and the authors of The Federalist) views of party. Political parties have been praised for ameliorating conflict by the accommodation of diverse groups and interests to maintain a consensus, and damned for being anti-democratic institutions that thwart popular majorities and threaten consensus by their repeated failure to confront serious public problems and to develop policy capable of resolving them. These conflicting views demonstrate inadequcy of present theoretical concepts of party. Adequate theoretical definition will help correct popular misconceptions of party which are, in part, the cause of disillusionment in minority groups and in the young.

RO-10475: Funds for cataloguing extensive collection of microfilm manuscripts. ABSTRACT: Funds for cataloguing extensive collection of microfilm manuscripts. Microfilm Library established at St. John's in 1964 in order to preserve all medieval manuscripts still extant in European monastic and allied libraries and of making these available to American scholars and students in a single center in the US. To date, approximately 9 million pages filmed and deposited at Library including writings on subjects from grammar and dialectic to law, medicine, philosophy, history, agriculture, history of science, etc. Adequate cataloguing is necessary for proper utilization of the collection. Many manuscript collections in Europe, often in monasteries which are isolated geographically, difficult of access and badly catalogued. For practical purposes they are as unavailable to European researchers as to American. By filming, centralizing and cataloging these manuscripts, St. John's will make a large and basic contribution to humanistic knowledge.

properties.ProjectTitle: Conference on Languages of the World
properties.ProjectDesc: Funds for the first and basic conference of distinguished linguistic scholars working toward the implementation of a program to describe the languages of the world. ABSTRACT: Funds for the first and basic conference of distinguished linguistic scholars working toward the implementation of a program to describe the languages of the world. At this conference 14 state-of-the-art papers (e.g., "Descriptive Adequacies in Linguistic," "Problems of Lexicon," "Language Standardization," "Universals in Language") will be presented by participants from the US. A few foreign observers will be invited to secure international cooperation. The conference will set guidelines to make future investigations more effective and increase cooperation among linguistic scholars in the contemporary undertaking. The only scholarly survey of the description of languages of the works is now very much outmoded due to advances in linguistic techniques since it was compiled. The project will describe languages in a more systematic way, using modern techniques. Project is timely because of the availability of technological aids as well as a large number of professional linguists in the world to complete the task. Conference should lead ultimately to the compilation of a handbook of background information about languages, such as language map-making, socio-linguistic information, their legal status and their varying designations; and a definition of the basic requirements for a description of the languages of the world. It will enable us to understand our own and other languages better.

Project to study how a particular event in the recent past, an Anarchist uprising in 1933 in Spain, and the peasants' perception of that event, relates to the iediological system of an Andalusian village. ABSTRACT: Project to study how a particular event in the recent past, an Anarchist uprising in 1933 in Spain, and the peasants' perception of that event, relates to the iediological system of an Andalusian village. By contrasting historical record with oral tradition concerning the uprising, the church, banditry, land tenure, working conditions, rise of anarchist movent, Civil War and its aftermath, PI aims to clarify historical record and provide greater understanding of revolutionary political movements in general as well as explore mechanisms for controlling social tension. Uprising had far-reaching consequences, one of the events which brought down the Spanish government and led to the Civil War; was covered in detail by newspapers and magaiznes throughout the coutry and subsequently by an official inquiry. PI, graduate assistant and informant to live in village for one year, collecting interviews, tapes, still photos, 16 mm film to suppliment previous researcy by PI under Ford Foundation grant.

Project to fill major gap in scholarly resources for the Victorian era by providing an Index to some 38 leading monthlies and quarterlies, 1824-1900. ABSTRACT: Project to fill major gap in scholarly resources for the Victorian era by providing an Index to some 38 leading monthies and quarterlies, 1824-1900. Such periodicals supply aspects of contemporary thought and current concerns which do not exist in published books. Index has four special interests; 1) tabular view of the contents, issue by issue, which also serves as record of subjects discussed at any given period and as book review index; 2) identification of anonymous and pseudonymous pieces (85%-90% of the total of the period), with references to sources in which material is reprinted wherever possible; 3) bibliographies of articles for each contributor (a resource never before available); 4) index of pseudonyms for English periodicals. Index in preparation since 1958, Vol. I published in 1966 by University of Toronto Press. Important tool for scholarship in the field of Victorian literature and thought. Funds for research assistants, 3 index/proofreaders, indirect costs.

Project to compile complete dictionary of the Yiddish language, from earliest extant records to the present world-wide dispersion of the language. ABSTRACT: Project to compile complete dictionary of the Yiddish language, from earliest extant records to the present world-wide dispersion of the language. Entries to include not only definitions and roots, but usages, social patterns and beliefs. Attempts to research entire field of Yiddish and complete comprehensive dictionary started prior to World War II in Europe and US. Most collections and compliled materials lost in war and most researchers and compilers eliminated under Nazis. Crucial that work be completed as soon as possible since number of scholars who have dealt with Yiddish as a "living" language rapridly diminishing. Qualified personnel being trained by grantee but no younger scholars have been raised with Yiddish as second language. Yiddish has played crucial role in Jewish history, linking Jews around the world in the last centuries. Key to Jewish culture and to the extent that this culture has influenced American culture, relevant also for America. Important nuances and meaning will be lost forever if project not completed during lifetime of aging Jewish scholars; insights into American and Jewish cultures will at same time disappear.

properties.ProjectDesc: To teach a course based on American texts and artifacts produced between 1800 and 1860. All texts to be used are profoundly political in nature. The materials will be analyzed not only in terms of political science, but also as literary documents. The course will be taught by one professor each from the departments of History and English.
